journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Educational and Behavioral Statistics

title-group.article-title: Student Mobility, Dosage, and Principal Stratification in School-Based RCTs

bio.title: Author
bio.p: PETER Z. SCHOCHET, PhD, is a senior fellow at Mathematica Policy Research, Inc., P.O. Box 2393, Princeton, NJ 08543; email: pschochet@mathematica-mpr.com. His areas of interest include causal inference underlying experiments, statistical power, clustered designs, regression discontinuity designs, propensity score matching designs, multiple testing, mediator analyses, value-added modeling, and conducting impact evaluations of education, employment, and welfare programs in the United States and abroad.

abstract.p: In school-based randomized control trials (RCTs), a common design is to follow student cohorts over time. For such designs, education researchers usually focus on the place-based (PB) impact parameter, which is estimated using data collected on all students enrolled in the study schools at each data collection point. A potential problem with this approach, however, is that the PB impact parameter could confound intervention effects on student mobility with more policy-relevant intervention effects on student achievement. Furthermore, the PB parameter pertains to students with different levels of intervention exposure, which complicates the interpretation of the impact findings. To address these issues, this article uses a principal stratification approach to examine the survivor average causal effect (SACE) parameter for original cohort students who would remain in their baseline study schools in either the treatment or control condition. The SACE parameter pertains to those who would receive maximum exposure to the intervention, and thus is a relevant parameter for dosage analyses. A strategy to estimate the SACE parameter is discussed using maximum likelihood (ML) methods for finite mixture models, the expectation-maximization (EM) algorithm, and robust standard errors to adjust for clustering. The estimation approach is demonstrated using data from a recent large-scale, school-based RCT where student mobility was common during the 3-year follow-up period.

body.p: In randomized control trials (RCTs) of educational interventions, random assignment is often performed at the school (or classroom) level rather than at the student level. These group-based designs are common, because RCTs in the education field often test interventions that provide enhanced services to teachers (such as professional development or mentoring services) or that test interventions that affect the entire school. Thus, for these types of interventions, it is infeasible to randomly assign the treatment directly to students.

Under these RCT designs, data are often collected on repeated cross sections of students as they progress into higher grades. A typical school-based RCT, for example, might collect baseline data on third graders in the fall of the first year of intervention implementation, and then collect follow-up data for this cohort in the spring of the third, fourth, and fifth grades. Thus, because students can move into and out of the study schools during the follow-up period, a critical issue for these RCTs is student mobility, which can affect the students for whom data are collected, the analysis samples, the choice of impact estimators, and the interpretation of study findings.

Student mobility is common, especially among low-income elementary and middle school students who are often the focus of large-scale RCTs funded by the U.S. Department of Education (ED) and foundations. Only about 55% of America’s kindergartners remain in the same school by the end of third grade (Burkham, Lee, & Dwyer, 2009), and the figures are considerably lower for African American children, students in poverty, and students in urban centers who often move both within and across school districts (de la Torre & Gwynne, 2009; Hanushek, Kain, & Rivkin, 2004; Pianta & Early, 2001; Sampson & Sharkey, 2008).

Research has found that the characteristics of students who change schools tend to differ from those who do not and that student mobility can have a negative effect on student learning (Raudenbush, Marshall, & Art, 2010; Reynolds, Chen, & Hebers, 2009). Thus, in school-based RCTs, the composition of students in the study schools could change over time, which could influence the size of the impact estimates and their interpretation. These issues are more problematic if the intervention has an effect on student mobility (Bloom, 2004).

There are several causal treatment effect parameters for school-based RCTs that address student mobility. The intention-to-treat (ITT) parameter, first introduced for nonclustered designs by Neyman (1923) and later developed in Rubin (1974, 1977) and Holland (1986), pertains to the average treatment effect (ATE) on key study outcomes for all treatment and control group students in the study schools at baseline. Under the ITT design, the initial cohort of students is followed over time, including those who remain in their initial study schools or transfer to other study schools—“stayers”—and those who leave the study schools—“leavers.” This approach yields causal impact findings that pertain to a well-defined student population. However, the ITT parameter may be difficult to interpret, because students in the ITT sample may have different levels of exposure to the intervention, which may not occur if the intervention were adopted more broadly.

The ITT design is rarely adopted for clustered education RCTs, however, because of the high cost of collecting outcome data for leavers across a potentially large number of geographically dispersed school districts. Thus, in many cases, ITT impacts can be estimated only if researchers impute missing outcome data for a potentially large number of leavers, which could be further complicated if the intervention has an effect on student mobility. These imputations are not typically performed.

Instead, a much more common approach is to focus on the place-based (PB) impact parameter, which pertains to the ATE for all students who are enrolled in the treatment and control schools at the follow-up data collection point (Boruch & Foley, 2000). This design, for instance, was used by all 25 large-scale, ED-funded RCTs that were recently conducted by the Regional Educational Laboratories (RELs). Under the PB design, the analysis sample includes stayers as well as students who transfer into the study schools between data collection points—“new entrants.”

The PB approach yields unbiased, school-based causal effect estimates under real-world conditions that include student mobility. However, if student mobility is common and is influenced by the intervention, the composition of students in the treatment and control schools could differ at each follow-up point. In this case, the PB parameter could confound intervention effects on student mobility with intervention effects on student achievement. For example, if the intervention induces higher achieving students to enter and remain in the treatment schools, then the PB parameter will reflect the achievement scores of these higher achieving students (mobility effects) as well as intervention effects for the “average” student in the study districts. Isolating these latter achievement effects, however, is likely to be of more interest to policymakers, because intervention effects on student mobility would not be germane if the intervention were adopted more broadly. Furthermore, similar to the ITT parameter, the PB parameter pertains to students with different levels of exposure to the intervention (because new entrants can enter the study schools at any time during the follow-up period), which complicates the interpretation of study findings. Finally, baseline pretest data are often missing for new entrants, which can further complicate the analysis.

To address these issues, this article introduces an alternative impact parameter for group-based RCTs with student mobility—the survivor average causal effect (SACE)—that pertains to the subpopulation of original cohort students who would remain in their baseline study schools in either the treatment or control condition. The SACE parameter has a clear interpretation, because it pertains to students who would receive maximum exposure to the intervention in the treatment condition and who would receive a common array of intervention services within a treatment school. Because intervention exposure is likely to be highly correlated with intervention dosage, the SACE parameter will typically be relevant for dosage analyses for many education RCTs. Consequently, the methods presented in this article can be used to address the following research question that is often of interest to education policymakers and evaluators: What are the intervention effects for the subgroup of students who receive a substantial amount of offered intervention services?

This article is the first to systematically examine the SACE parameter for clustered education RCTs with student mobility. The article uses a principal stratification (PS) and potential outcomes approach following the work of Frangakis and Rubin (2002), Little and Yau (1998), Rubin (2006), and Zhang, Rubin, and Mealli (2009). This article is also the first to use the PS approach to define and compare the ITT, PB, and SACE parameters.

In the present context, the PS approach for the SACE parameter involves allocating students in the initial cohort sample to unobserved principal strata defined by students’ potential mobility statuses in the treatment and control conditions. One stratum, for example, might contain students who would remain in their study schools as a treatment, but not as a control. We cannot generally determine the specific principal stratum membership for a student, because mobility decisions are only observed in either the treatment or control condition, but not both. However, we can identify the SACE parameter by invoking distributional assumptions on potential outcomes for students in each research condition and principal stratum, and using maximum likelihood (ML) methods for finite mixture models (see, e.g., McLachlan & Peel, 2000). This approach yields consistent estimates of the SACE parameter and stratum population shares.

This PS approach to conducting RCT dosage analyses does not rely on hard-to-find instrumental variables to identify causal effects for analyses that compare the outcomes of self-selected samples of stayers in the treatment and control groups (Heckman & Robb, 1985). It also does not rely on propensity score matching methods (Rosenbaum & Rubin, 1983; Schochet & Burghardt, 2007) or other regression-based approaches (Peck, 2003) that rely solely on highly predictive covariates that are correlated with study outcomes to match treatment stayers with comparable controls (or vice versa). Finally, the PS approach differs from methods that place bounds on causal effects for stayers (see, e.g., Imai, 2008; Zhang & Rubin, 2003).

This article demonstrates the developed PS approach using data from the Social and Character Development (SACD) Research Program, a large-scale, school-based RCT funded by the Institute of Education Sciences (IES) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC; SACD Research Consortium, 2010). The SACD study evaluated promising school-based interventions in 84 schools in seven sites that were designed to promote positive social and character development among elementary school children. For this study, student mobility was common over the 3-year follow-up period.

This remainder of this article is in four sections. Section 1 discusses the PS approach that underlies the ITT, PB, and SACE parameters, and Section 2 discusses identification and estimation issues for the SACE parameter for the empirical study. Section 3 presents case study findings using the SACD data, and Section 4 presents a summary and conclusions.

sec.title: 1. The Principal Stratification Approach
sec.p:
Consider a commonly used RCT design in education research where n study schools are randomly assigned to either a single treatment or control group within each evaluation site (e.g., a school district), where p is the sampling rate to the treatment group
( 0 < p < 1 )

It is assumed that there is an area

m A
students in the relevant grades who could potentially move into the study schools during the follow-up period (i.e., who could be new entrants). The definition of this outside area is likely to depend on the RCT context (e.g., whether the study is being conducted in an urban or remote rural area, economic conditions that could affect family mobility, etc.).

The next subsections discuss the PS approach for the original student cohort and for students in A. This framework is used to define and compare the ITT, PB, and SACE parameters. We assume a cross-sectional impact analysis that aims to estimate intervention effects using outcome data from the final follow-up data collection point.

The SUTVA mobility condition implies that a student’s decision to stay in his or her initial school or to leave the study school districts will not depend on the treatment or control assignments of other study schools. SUTVA implies also that if a student decides to transfer to a treatment school, the student will be equally likely to transfer to each one, and similarly for control schools. This may be plausible if the study schools within a study site are similar and evenly dispersed over a relatively small catchment area, but may be less realistic if students have preferences for specific schools. The SUTVA condition for potential outcomes is likely to be plausible unless there is substantial interaction between students and staff across study schools (Hong & Raudenbush, 2006, discuss violations to SUTVA). Equations 6, 7a, and 7b formally demonstrate how the PB parameter can confound treatment effects on mobility with treatment effects on student achievement. If mobility effects are present, the treatment and control group samples will be representative of somewhat different student populations. Furthermore, the stratum weights for the mean potential outcomes (that is, the

There is another interesting scenario where the PB*, PB, and ITT parameters are likely to be similar. Suppose that the intervention has no effect on student mobility and that the study sites are randomly selected from the combined study catchment and A areas. In this case, the expected number and composition of new entrants will be the same as for the original cohort leavers. Furthermore, expected exposure to the intervention will equate for the two groups, although the leavers will tend to receive intervention services earlier. Thus, in this scenario, the PB and ITT parameters will be similar if impacts are independent of when intervention services are received.
The above analysis suggests that researchers should conduct the following analyses to help interpret the PB impact estimates:

list-item.p: Examine the prevalence of student mobility. If student mobility in and out of the study schools is rare, the ITT, SACE, PB*, and PB parameters will be similar.

Estimate intervention effects on student mobility rates and the timing of school transfers during the follow-up period. If mobility is common, but there are no impacts on student mobility (and on the composition of students who transfer), the PB estimates pertain to treatment effects on student achievement that are not confounded by treatment effects on mobility. Furthermore, as discussed, if there are no impacts on mobility, the PB and ITT parameters will be similar if the study schools can be considered a random sample from a broader school population and intervention effects are independent of when services are received.

Compare the baseline characteristics of leavers and new entrants in the treatment and control groups. Treatment-control differences in the characteristics of leavers could reflect the presence of intervention effects on the composition of students who transfer, and similarly for new entrants. Differences between the characteristics of leavers and new entrants within a research condition could indicate that the SACE, PB, and ITT parameters pertain to different student populations and that the study schools cannot be considered a random sample from a broader school population. For similar reasons, it is important also to use available data to directly compare the characteristics of the study schools to a broader sample of schools.

Assess whether treatment effects are constant. As discussed, if the intervention has no effect on student mobility, then the PB, ITT, and SACE parameters equate if ATEs are constant across principal strata. To examine this issue, researchers could examine the heterogeneity of estimated PB impacts for baseline subgroups defined by student, school, and site characteristics, and using quantile regression methods (Koenker, 2005).

Examine changes in intervention services over time. The PB parameter pertains to students who may have entered the study schools at different times during the follow-up period. Thus, to help interpret the PB estimates and to compare the ITT and PB parameters, it is important to document the evolution of intervention services over the follow-up period.

sec.title: 2. Identification and Estimation of the SACE Parameter for the Case Study
sec.p: For the case study using data from the SACD evaluation, the SACE parameter was estimated using the original cohort sample of stayers (who have available outcome and baseline data) and leavers (who have baseline data only). The new entrants sample was not included in the analysis because data are not typically observed for students in area A who do not enter the study schools; this censoring complicates the likelihood function contribution for the new entrants.

Principal strata for the analysis were defined using several features of the SACD data. First, less than 2% of the SACD sample transferred to other study schools during the 3-year follow-up period. Thus, these students were categorized as leavers and the
T t
and
C t
mobility statuses were omitted for the analysis. Second, the SACD data do not contain information on the exact transfer dates for leavers, but only that they were no longer in the study schools at a specific follow-up interview date. Thus, to simplify the analysis, leavers—denoted as L—were classified as those in the initial cohort who ever left their initial schools between baseline and the third spring follow-up interview. Accordingly, there are two mobility statuses for the analysis: stayers (S) and leavers (L).

Although not necessary for identification of the SACE parameter (see below), we invoke the following monotonicity assumption to further reduce the number of principal strata and model parameters for the empirical analysis:

Assumption 2: Monotonicity: If

.

sec.p: This assumption means that the original cohort of students will be at least as likely to transfer schools as controls than treatments. While this assumption may not always be realistic, large-scale education RCTs typically test interventions that have been shown by smaller scale studies to be effective in improving key student outcomes. Thus, in many RCTs, it seems reasonable to hypothesize that beneficial program impacts on student outcomes will lead to reductions in treatment group mobility. However, analysts can invoke a “reverse” monotonicity assumption to Assumption 2 if estimated impacts on mobility have a positive sign or can invoke no mobility assumption.

sec.p: Parameter identification for the model arises solely from the normality assumptions for the potential outcomes (by far the most common distribution used in mixture modeling). Violations to normality can yield biased estimates. Thus, transforming outcomes so that they look more normal (e.g., by taking logs) can increase the credibility of model assumptions. 1

Importantly, covariates are not required for identification but are used in the analysis to increase the precision of the impact estimates by helping to predict missing potential outcomes and mobility statuses. Furthermore, as pointed out by Zhang et al. (2009), the use of covariates can improve the plausibility of assumptions, such as normality of the potential outcome distributions, because they are conditional on the covariates. In addition, Griffin, McCaffery, and Morral (2008) find that covariates improve model identification if there is little separation in the mixture distributions. Nonetheless, covariates play a much less important role in the principal stratification approach than in propensity score matching which relies solely on the availability of baseline covariates that are highly correlated with mobility decisions and student outcomes.

Finally, with many model parameters, the EM algorithm for mixture models can be slow to converge and sensitive to starting values (see, e.g., Griffin, et al., 2008; McLachlan, 1988). Thus, in applying the PS approach, researchers must carefully assess the robustness of study findings to alternative starting values and model covariates. Furthermore, if possible, the number of principal strata should be minimized so that stratum means can be uniquely identified. This is a key reason why Assumption 2 was invoked for the case study to reduce the number of model parameters for analysis.

sec.title: 3. Case Study Findings Using the SACD Data
sec.p: The SACD study evaluated promising school-based interventions in 84 elementary schools in seven sites that were designed to promote positive social and character development among elementary school children. The interventions, which were implemented in the summer prior to the start of the study, aimed to help schools foster positive behaviors and reduce negative behaviors among students, and ultimately improve students’ academic performance. Within each site, half the schools were randomly assigned to a treatment group and half were randomly assigned to a control group. Intervention features differed somewhat across programs but typically included materials and lessons on social skills, behavior management, social and emotional learning, self-control, anger management, and violence prevention. For all programs, the activities were integrated and organized based on a theory of action, were implemented in the schools by school personnel, and were administered to all students in all elementary classrooms in a school. Table 3 displays information on the seven study sites, the tested interventions, and baseline and final follow-up sample sizes of schools and students (see the SACD Research Consortium, 2010, for further details). 3

sec.p: The child-level impact analysis for the evaluation used data on a repeated cross section of students progressing through the upper elementary school grades: third graders in school year 2004–2005, fourth graders in school year 2005–2006, and fifth graders in school year 2006–2007. Baseline data were collected in Fall 2004 for the original student cohort, and follow-up data were collected in Spring 2005, 2006, and 2007 for original cohort stayers and new entrants. Follow-up data were not collected for original cohort leavers, so the ITT parameter could not be estimated. Data were obtained from child reports administered in the classroom, primary caregiver telephone interviews, and teacher reports on students.

Using the methods described above, the SACD data were used to estimate the multisite SACE and PB impact parameters as well as the

Three outcomes were examined to assess the robustness of study findings. 4 Larger outcome values are associated with more beneficial outcomes.

sec.p: The SACD evaluation found no statistically significant PB impact estimates on any outcome, including the three considered here (SACD Research Consortium, 2010). However, because mobility into and out of the study schools was common (see below), only about two thirds of the students in the Spring 2007 follow-up interview sample were original cohort stayers; thus, the SACD interventions may have had a beneficial SACE effect for students who received maximum exposure to intervention services.

For the analysis, a set of baseline covariates
(
X
i j
)
(listed below) that were constructed using Fall 2004 data were included in the multinomial logit and outcome regression models. These covariates included demographic information on the child, information on the child’s caregiver and household, and pre-intervention (pretest) measures of the outcomes. These covariates were selected because of their significant correlations with the study outcomes and with student mobility decisions and are similar to the covariates that were used in the impact models for the SACD evaluation (SACD Research Consortium, 2010).

sec.title: 3.1. Contextual Analyses
sec.p: Study mobility was common during the 3-year study period (Table 5). About one third of students in the original third-grade cohort were no longer in the study schools by the spring of the fifth-grade year (the transfer rate was about 53% in Chicago; 40% in New York City; one third in Buffalo, North Carolina, and Tennessee; 27% in Rochester/Minnesota; and 17% in Maryland). About 6% of the original cohort left the study schools between Fall 2004 and Spring 2005, 18% left between Spring 2005 and Spring 2006, and 10% left between Spring 2006 and Spring 2007. A slightly smaller percentage, 30%, of all students in the fifth-grade sample were new entrants (the new entry rate ranged from about 20% in Maryland to 40% in Chicago). Thus, student sample sizes were slightly larger in Fall 2004 than in Spring 2007.

sec.p: Importantly, there were no statistically significant differences between the unadjusted mobility rates for students in the treatment and control schools at each follow-up point (Table 5). Furthermore, as shown in Table 6, there were no treatment-control differences between the baseline characteristics of stayers, leavers, and new entrants. This suggests that the SACD interventions did not appear to have an effect on the composition of students in the study schools during the follow-up period (this issue is examined more formally below).

sec.p: There were, however, statistically significant differences between the baseline characteristics of stayers and leavers within each research group. Consistent with the previous literature (see, e.g., Raudenbush et al., 2010), stayers tended to be less disadvantaged than leavers; stayers were more likely to be White, to be from two-parent and higher income households, to have more educated caregivers, and to have higher pretest scores for nearly all of the academic and behavioral scales. These results highlight the key point that the SACE parameter in education RCTs will typically pertain to a different student population than the ITT or PB parameters. Thus, the SACE parameter could differ from the other parameters not only because the SACE parameter pertains to students with higher average exposure to the intervention but also because there might be heterogeneity of treatment effects across student subgroups defined by their baseline levels of risk.

Table 6 shows that the new entrants and leavers had similar baseline characteristics. In addition, as shown in Table 5 from above, there were no significant differences between the entry and leaver rates at each follow-up point, suggesting that the new entrants and leavers were exposed to intervention services for a similar amount of time (although the new entrants received services later in the period). These results suggest that the SACD sites can be considered a random sample from a broader set of areas from which the new entrants and original student cohort came. This suggests that the ITT and PB impact parameters could be similar, as long as SACD intervention services did not differ substantially during the period when leavers and new entrants were exposed to them.

sec.p: Table 7 shows that the regression-adjusted mean outcomes for the control group were slightly larger for the SACE than PB population, reflecting the finding from above that the SACE population was somewhat less disadvantaged. However, the estimated impacts for both the SACE and PB parameters are not statistically significant at the 5% level for all three outcomes (Table 7). For the engagement with learning scale, the impact estimates are about −0.04 standard deviations for both impact parameters. For the positive social behavior scale, the SACE impact estimate (0.08 standard deviations) is larger than for the PB parameter (0.04 standard deviations), which could partly reflect the higher level of intervention services received by the SACE population, but both impacts are not statistically significant. A similar pattern of impacts holds for the empathy scale. These findings are consistent with the results presented in the SACD Research Consortium report (2010) that found that estimated PB impacts were statistically insignificant for a host of population subgroups.

The finding that the SACD interventions had little effect on student mobility suggests that the SACE impacts could be estimated by comparing the outcomes of stayers in the treatment and control groups using standard HLM methods, which yields nearly identical impact and standard error estimates as the SACE estimates in Table 7 (not shown). Similarly, causal impacts for the new entrant population could be estimated by comparing the outcomes of new entrants in the two research groups.

sec.title: 4. Summary and Conclusions
sec.p: In school-based RCTs of education interventions, a common design is to follow student cohorts over time. For such designs, education researchers usually focus on the place-based (PB) impact parameter, which is estimated using data collected on all students who are enrolled in the study schools at each data collection point. This sample includes original cohort stayers and new entrants, but not original cohort leavers (whose data are required for an ITT impact analysis).

A potential problem with the PB approach, however, is that if the tested interventions have an effect on the proportion and composition of students entering and leaving the study schools, the PB impact parameter could confound intervention effects on student mobility with intervention effects on student achievement for the “average” student in the study schools. These latter effects, however, are likely to be of more interest to policymakers, largely because treatment effects on mobility would not exist if the intervention were adopted more broadly. Furthermore, the PB parameter pertains to students who have been exposed to the intervention for different amounts of time, which clouds the interpretation of study findings. As shown in this article, if the intervention influences student mobility, the PB parameter is difficult to interpret and estimate using a potential outcomes framework that underlies experiments.

To address these issues, this article used a principal stratification (PS) approach to define the SACE parameter for group-based RCTs with student mobility. This parameter pertains to the subpopulation of original cohort students who would remain in their baseline study schools in either the treatment or control condition. The SACE parameter is of policy interest, because it pertains to students with maximum exposure to the intervention, and hence, who receive a substantial dose of intervention services (to the extent that the intervention is implemented properly and treatment students receive the intended services). Maximum intervention exposure may not be synonymous with full dosage. Nonetheless, the SACE parameter will typically be a relevant parameter for dosage analyses for many school-based RCTs.

The article discussed estimation of the SACE parameter using ML methods for finite mixture models, the EM algorithm, and robust Huber standard errors to adjust for school-level clustering. Under this approach, identification of the SACE parameter is driven by distributional assumptions about potential student outcomes within each principal stratum. The article also used the PS approach to rigorously define and contrast the PB, ITT, and SACE impact parameters, and discussed simple contextual analyses for comparing and interpreting them.

The estimation of the SACE impact parameter was demonstrated using data from a large-scale, group-based RCT that evaluated promising school-based interventions that were designed to promote positive social and character development among elementary school children. For this study, about 34% of students left the study schools and a slightly smaller percentage entered the study schools during the 3-year follow-up period. Very small treatment effects on student mobility were found during the follow-up period. However, original cohort stayers in both research groups were found to be less disadvantaged than both the leavers and the new entrants, highlighting the important point that the SACE and PB parameters in education RCTs will often pertain to different student populations. Most importantly, we found that the SACE and PB impacts on three key study behavioral and academic outcomes were all statistically insignificant, suggesting that the SACD interventions did not have beneficial effects, even for the subpopulation of stayers who received maximum exposure to intervention services.

Although not necessary for identification, the PS approach developed in this article is likely to be most successful if detailed baseline data are available to model missing student mobility statuses and potential outcomes, thereby improving the precision of the parameter estimates. Thus, the collection of detailed baseline data (and in particular, pretest data) are important in school-based RCTs in the education area, not only to improve precision of the PB impact estimates (Raudenbush, 1997; Schochet, 2008) and to adjust for missing data (Puma, Olsen, Bell, & Price, 2009) but also to rigorously estimate policy-relevant impact parameters for the subpopulation of original cohort stayers.

A contribution of this article was the development of rigorous statistical methods to estimate maximum treatment exposure (dosage) effects in education RCTs. The estimation of the SACE parameter for such an analysis provides a viable alternative to instrumental variable methods that rely on hard-to-find instruments and propensity score methods that rely solely on predictive baseline covariates to match treatment and control group stayers. Dosage effects are often of policy concern in education RCTs to assess whether impacts are larger for those who receive more intervention services. Clearly, levels of intervention dosage cannot always be mandated. However, understanding program effects for those who are exposed to intervention services for the full follow-up period provides policy-relevant information on likely program effects that would be observed if intervention implementation was improved or became more widespread. Thus, the estimation of the SACE parameter can strengthen the overall impact findings in education RCTs.

The case study and estimation methods examined in this article applied to a design with two mobility statuses (stayers and leavers) and three principal strata. The same methods can be adapted to designs with additional mobility groups and principal strata. However, in such designs, computational complexities (such as model convergence) and parameter identification could arise as the number of model parameters increase significantly. An area for future research is to empirically assess the computational feasibility of using the PS approach for designs with multiple stayer and leaver groups, and the specification of additional design assumptions (such as monotonicity conditions) that could be required to reduce the number of principal strata and model parameters for estimation.

Finally, the methods developed in this article apply to other contexts. For example, mobility issues also pertain to clustered RCTs of health interventions where hospitals or physicians are the unit of randomization and longitudinal data are collected on patients.

The EM algorithm is an iterative estimation procedure which consists of an expectation (E) step where the missing indicator functions are imputed, and a maximization step (M) where Equation A1 is maximized using the imputations from the E-step. The iterations were considered to have converged when the maximum change in the parameter estimates between successive iterations was less than 0.0001. The change was a relative change if the parameter was greater than 0.01 in absolute value; otherwise, it was an absolute change.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The author received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
Nonparametric mixture modeling methods (see, e.g., Lindsay, 1983) have been developed, but the application of these methods to our scenario is beyond the scope of this article.

Frankakis, Rubin, and Zhou (2002) discuss a fully Bayesian inference PS approach for RCT designs with noncompliance that directly models group-level clustering. Calculating standard errors using bootstrapping where schools are resampled with replacement a large number of times (say 1,000) is very computationally intensive due to the slow convergence of the EM algorithm.
A restricted data use agreement was obtained from IES in order to use the SACD data for the analysis.

About 3% of students had missing outcome data because they were absent from school at the time the assessments were administered. To account for these missing data, the analyses presented below were conducted using sample weights that were constructed for the SACD evaluation to adjust for interview nonresponse.
